SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He attributes these symptoms to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms for approximately five weeks. He has been adhering to his medications but admits to struggling with his diet due to the construction in his kitchen, leading to eating out more frequently and consuming less healthy food options.

The patient denies fever, chills, and significant shortness of breath. He reports slight chest cramps that resolve within an hour and a mild cough. He has been monitoring his blood pressure regularly and reports it has been well-controlled.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive for slight chest cramps. No significant shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Positive for a mild cough. No significant wheezing or dyspnea.
• Gastrointestinal: Positive for bloating. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor daily weight and report any significant weight gain or worsening shortness of breath. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure has been well-controlled with current medication.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation is present. No pain in the calves.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a 2-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. Since then, his back has been stiff. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used icy heat, but these did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having home-cooked meals recently. He plans to improve his diet.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, which resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He is managing his depression well with medication.

Regarding his hypertension, he is mostly compliant with his Norvasc medication during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. His blood pressure in the office today is 120/80 mmHg.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He reports occasional shortness of breath during humid weather and when running 4-5 miles daily. He also experiences some chest pounding during exertion, which resolves.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing well with Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill prescription for Prozac 20 mg daily.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is mostly compliant with Norvasc and has improved blood pressure control.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also reports worsening anxiety and depression. Ms. Cooper has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy (1996).

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: occasional, once or twice a year.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for improved iron absorption. Reassess blood work in 8-12 weeks.
2. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
3. Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule appointments for upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and hematologist. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy. Call clinic with any additional concerns or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidentally discovered pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, and all other results were normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. Non-smoker, non-drinker, and no recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery to assess for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient visited the ER, where she underwent a normal cardiac workup, including EKG and blood tests. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient has not experienced any chest pain or difficulty swallowing since the initial episode in October 2020.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Esophagitis (suspected).

Surgical
Cholecystectomy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

No significant social history provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None reported.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for weight loss, abdominal pain, and abnormal bowel movements.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which have since resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAM

The patient has mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. The rest of the exam is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms have resolved, and she has been asymptomatic for three months. It is suspected that she may have had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contributions from musculoskeletal etiologies.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. The patient should follow up as needed for any other GI complaints or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. She has had issues with feeding and regulating her temperature in the past, and currently sees a GI doctor for reflux. Katherine is in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She is also scheduled to start speech therapy in the next couple of weeks. The patient has seen an orthopedic doctor, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned that patients with this syndrome may have kidney issues, prompting this visit.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Feeding difficulties.
Reflux.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
2. If the ultrasound shows abnormalities, determine next steps and future follow-up.
3. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.
4. Follow-up should be at the Town Center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow up as needed based on the findings.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ACE wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any prior injuries to her right arm. She reports some tingling in her fingers but is still able to feel them.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Positive for tingling in fingers, denies numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not recorded.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient is in mild distress due to pain.
HEENT: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling and ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation throughout, bony crepitus, pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace for her right wrist. I have also recommended surgery to properly align and stabilize the fracture. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. Following surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for rehabilitation. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should continue to ice her wrist and take pain medication as prescribed. She should follow up with the office in one month to assess her progress and discuss her vacation plans. If her pain worsens or she experiences any complications, she should contact the office immediately.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Edema and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing knee pain and swelling. Physical exam and x-ray results support the diagnosis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support. Advise icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to elevate and rest the leg, avoiding heavy work on the property for a couple of weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg of lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg of lisinopril. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to help manage sodium intake and improve overall diet.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant male patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to feel like she might fall. This occurs less than once a day and resolves quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for the pain, as it does not last long. The patient is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve a lot of walking and line dancing, and is unsure if she will be able to participate due to her knee issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medications regularly.

Endocrine: Reports taking metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension management and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family members and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat. Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies difficulty swallowing or feeling of food getting stuck.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with the current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose of 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of therapy to assess for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a dry cough and bilateral crackles on lung exam, with mild radiation pneumonitis on chest X-ray.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports a persistent sore throat, likely due to inflammation from radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds that linger for a long time, especially during the winter season. No recent history of abdominal infections or diarrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works at a family-owned donut shop.

TRAVEL HISTORY

Recent international travel to Zambia.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits, no fever.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows a low IgA level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not seem to have frequent respiratory tract, sinus, or abdominal infections that would be concerning.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibodies and potential immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to monitor for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever require blood products.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He has recently started doing pottery, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has recently started doing pottery.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest his elbow, wear a sling while awake, apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. He is also advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in one week to evaluate his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain and shortness of breath.
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes and goes. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. The patient has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past. His father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Urinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for pain relief.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain his urine and monitor for the passage of the stone.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to evaluate progress. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient describes the ulcer as initially a blister with stinging pain, which has progressed to a throbbing pain. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with some improvement in symptoms, but recently noticed blackening around the wound and cramping in his calf muscle. He also reports a red streak along the inside of his calf muscle and increased warmth in the area. The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks, with occasional spikes up to 500.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports enjoying hiking and recently went on a hike with new diabetic shoes and inserts.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever of 99.7 and chills prior to starting antibiotics.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and shortness of breath in the past few days.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with blackening and red streak.
Neurological: No numbness or tingling.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided.
Heart rate: Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
RESPIRATORY: Not provided.
NECK: Not provided.
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Pain in the calf muscle.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent poor blood sugar control
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed the current symptoms and plan with the patient. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound. A debridement will be performed in the office today, and a culture will be taken to assess for possible changes in antibiotic therapy. The patient will continue the current antibiotic course and follow up in 7 days. The patient is advised to closely monitor blood sugars and follow up with their endocrinologist to maintain hemoglobin A1c below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in the yard. Patient noticed a tick bite on the right knee over a week ago, which has been burning and causing discomfort.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, body aches, cough, shortness of breath, or dizziness.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain in joints, but no new joint pain since tick bite.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not recorded
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with tick bite on right knee, bull's-eye rash, and symptoms of headache and malaise since the bite.
- Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order Hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
